name: 程聖倫
objective: This is a course designed to provide an introduction to the principles and methods of statistics using R. The overall goal of the course is to provide graduate students with a foundation for quantitative data analysis that will allow them to build future skills. This course provides an applied approach to statistical analysis for research. Topics include an introduction to univariate and bivariate distributions, data displays, descriptive statistics, the standard normal distribution, student’s t distribution, inferential statistical methods for testing means, correlation, simple/multiple linear regression, and mediation. This course also introduces the student to the R data analysis system. No formal course prerequisites.
schedule:
01: Course Introduction 
02: Review: Research Methods 

[Descriptive]

03: Analyzing Data: Descriptives & Going Beyond 
04: The Concept of Statistical Modeling 
05: Making Inferences about Populations 
06: Testing Research Questions 
07: Data Displays & Graphs 
08: Statistical Assumptions and Bias 
09: Mid-term 

[Relational]

10: Relations Between Variables (bivariate correlation) 
11: Predictions (simple linear regression & multiple linear regression) 
12: Simple Mediation Model
13: Parallel Multiple Mediator Model
14: Parallel Multiple Mediator Model with Multiple Causal Antecedents
15: Parallel Multiple Mediator Model with Multiple Causal Antecedents and Consequent Variables

[Experimental]

16: Mean Comparisons: t-test (independent and paired) 
17: General Linear Model: ANOVA & ANCOVA
18: Final
materials:
Field, A., Miles, J., & Field, Z. (2013). Discovering statistics using R. Sage.

Navarro, D. (2019). Learning statistics with R: A tutorial for psychology students and other beginners. (https://learningstatisticswithr.com/book/index.html).
